senses.sense: the study of a subject in detail to find information or to gain a better understanding of it

senses.sense: the solution to a problem

senses.sense: an official decision that is made after a group or organization has voted

senses.sense: to say or do something as a reaction to something that has been said or done

senses.sense: relating to each of the people or things that you have just talked about

senses.sense: to admire someone because of their knowledge, achievements, etc.

senses.sense: when someone tells their employer that they are leaving their job
senses.dict_examp: a letter of resignation

senses.sense: when you accept something that you do not like because you cannot easily change it

senses.sense: a feeling of anger about a situation that you think is unfair

senses.sense: to arrange to have a seat on an aircraft, a room in a hotel, etc.

senses.sense: ready to be used if or when you need it

senses.sense: a supply of something that you keep until it is needed

senses.sense: a place where many people go on vacation or for an activity they enjoy

senses.sense: admired by people because of your knowledge, achievements, etc.

senses.sense: involving or related to the sale of products to customers for their own use

senses.sense: to limit something

senses.sense: controlled or limited

senses.sense: to go back to the usual condition

senses.sense: in exchange for something or as a reaction to something

senses.lear_examp: My parents decided to move to a small village when I was just a kid. Shortly after we settled in, my parents decided that I was running wild and that it was time for me to receive some sort of education.

senses.sense: If someone's imagination runs wild, they are not able to control their thoughts.
senses.dict_examp: It was getting dark and my imagination was starting to run wild.
senses.lear_examp: Her imagination started to run wild and she began to think about the dark corridors, the secret passages and the obscure dungeons that the castle might hide.

senses.sense: to be very busy doing a lot of different things
senses.dict_examp: I'm exhausted, I've been running around all morning.
senses.lear_examp: Nowadays people are running around trying to save time wherever they can, when in reality time passes far quicker when we try to save it.

senses.sense: to secretly leave a place because you are unhappy there
senses.dict_examp: She ran away from home at the age of 13.
senses.lear_examp: At the age of fourteen, she ran away from home.

senses.sense: to criticize someone or something, often unfairly
senses.dict_examp: Whatever the government do, the press will always run them down.
senses.lear_examp: But it's not fair to run down my country's past achievements.

senses.sense: to accidentally hit something while you are driving a vehicle
senses.dict_examp: He lost control of the car and ran into a tree.
senses.lear_examp: I had tried to stop my car next to the road but I ran into a signpost.

senses.sense: to meet someone that you know when you did not expect to meet them
senses.dict_examp: I ran into Harry on the train.
senses.lear_examp: We ran into an old friend of mine and we decided to have a coffee together.

senses.sense: If a machine runs on a supply of power, it uses that power to work.
senses.dict_examp: My laptop is running on battery power.
senses.lear_examp: Public transport will be quick and free, and run on electric power, so there won't be car pollution.

senses.sense: to finish, use or sell all of something, so that there is none left
senses.dict_examp: I've run out of money/ideas/patience.
senses.lear_examp: Well, I have run out of time, so I have to stop writing.

senses.sense: If a supply of something runs out, all of it has been used or it is completely finished.
senses.dict_examp: We've  run out of milk.
senses.lear_examp: In addition, if you are at home and something you need has run out or broken, you can go to buy it at any time.

senses.sense: to hit someone or something with a vehicle and drive over them, injuring or killing them
senses.dict_examp: He was run over by a bus.
senses.lear_examp: After a while, his father vanished and a car ran over John and killed him.

senses.sense: to repeat something in order to practice it or to make sure that it is correct
senses.dict_examp: I just need to run through my talk.

senses.sense: If you run up against problems or difficulties, you begin to experience them.
senses.dict_examp: The plan for the park ran up against strong local opposition.
senses.lear_examp: After running up against a lot of difficulties we managed to reach our hotel.

senses.sense: when you move on your feet at a speed faster than walking, especially for exercise
senses.dict_examp: We go for a three-mile run every evening after work.
senses.lear_examp: Walking is recognized as good exercise, or going for a run.

senses.sense: in baseball or cricket, a single point
senses.dict_examp: They scored three runs in the ninth inning to win the game.
senses.lear_examp: I liked the competition because both the teams played well and they scored good runs.

senses.sense: at a time that is far away in the future
senses.dict_examp: It seems a lot of effort but I'm sure it's the best solution in the long run.
senses.lear_examp: It costs a lot of money, but in the long run, it is worth it.

senses.sense: to suddenly run fast in order to escape from somewhere
senses.dict_examp: When he saw the open door, he made a run for it.
senses.lear_examp: Anna and Tom decided to make a run for it.

senses.sense: when something happens several times without something different happening during that period
senses.dict_examp: a run of 10 games without a win
senses.lear_examp: Strange though it may seem, he achieved success in every possible field not owing to a run of good luck, but thanks to his outstanding qualities.

senses.sense: in a way that is not polite
senses.dict_examp: He pushed past us rudely.
senses.lear_examp: When I made an attempt to speak to the conductor, I was rudely told off and told to stay seated for the rest of the trip.

senses.sense: an official legal decision, usually made by a judge
senses.dict_examp: The Supreme Court decided not to review the lower court’s ruling.
senses.lear_examp: As you certainly will remember, the ruling of the High Court obliges you to keep the level of noise below a certain level depending on the distance of the airport.

senses.sense: a flat, straight stick which is used to measure things
senses.dict_examp: Can I borrow your ruler?
senses.lear_examp: We have to bring with us a pencil and a ruler for the first lesson.

senses.sense: the leader of a country
senses.dict_examp: He was the ruler of the country for over 20 years.
senses.lear_examp: Versailles in France and the time of Louis XIV as the ruler would be my place and time I would choose to visit.

senses.sense: a soft piece of material used to cover the floor
senses.dict_examp: My dog loves lying on the rug in front of the fire.
senses.lear_examp: There is a green rug in the middle of the floor.

senses.sense: a manner and attitude that is impolite
senses.dict_examp: I was shocked by her rudeness.
senses.lear_examp: Furthermore, a person who is focused only on his goals will try to show off all his/her abilities, they will try to demonstrate their intelligence and their power to the others sometimes with rudeness and intolerance.

senses.sense: information that a lot of people are talking about although they do not know if it is true
senses.dict_examp: Rumors about teacher layoffs are circulating at school.
senses.lear_examp: He owned an inn called Jamaica but nobody would go there anymore due to some strange rumors.

senses.sense: in a bad situation where you do the same things all the time, or where it is impossible to make progress
senses.dict_examp: He seems to be stuck in a rut at the moment.
senses.lear_examp: Financial security, all the, let me call them, background benefits are important, but if you do not love what you do, soon you will become bitter, stuck in a rut or worse - you will suffer from depression.

senses.sense: the sport of moving on your feet at a speed faster than walking
senses.dict_examp: I go running three times a week.
senses.lear_examp: My hobbies are reading and running.

senses.sense: the activity of controlling or looking after something
senses.dict_examp: The running of a large household is not easy.
senses.lear_examp: Electricity is an essential requirement now in the day-to-day running of businesses and life in general compared to the early nineteenth century.

senses.sense: If something happens for the second/third, etc., day/week, etc., running, it happens on that number of regular occasions without changing.
senses.dict_examp: He's won the Championship for the fifth year running.
senses.lear_examp: Fourteen days running of laziness and sleep without tight-scheduled meetings or rush-hour traffic jams lurking.

senses.sense: If a building has running water, water comes into  it through pipes.
senses.dict_examp: The summer homes on the island have no running water.
senses.lear_examp: It is hilarious to think that at the same time people in the north of Europe were still living a primitive and uncivilized life not even able to invent an axe, the Romans managed to install running water in their huge houses.

senses.sense: Rusty metal has rust  on its surface.
senses.dict_examp: a rusty car/nail
senses.lear_examp: It was very rusty but I repainted it and now it looks like a new bike.

senses.sense: If a skill you had is now rusty, it is no longer good because you have forgotten it.
senses.dict_examp: My French is a bit rusty.
senses.lear_examp: However, I am rather "rusty" at using the morse code as well as using the codes of communication.

senses.sense: a large road that aircraft use to land on or to start flying from
senses.dict_examp: The runway was covered with snow.
senses.lear_examp: The problem hit the headlines when a small Soviet aircraft missed the runway and touched down on a road exploding in two pieces and damaging many cars and the people sitting inside.

senses.sense: not caring if you hurt or upset other people when you try to get what you want
senses.dict_examp: ruthless ambition
senses.lear_examp: As a result, the competition has become ruthless and severe.

senses.sense: to move on your feet at a faster speed than walking
senses.dict_examp: He can run very fast.
senses.lear_examp: Children can run everywhere.

senses.sense: to organize or control something
senses.dict_examp: She ran her own restaurant for five years.
senses.lear_examp: My aunt is always working. She runs her own business.

senses.sense: If trains or buses are running, they are available to travel on.
senses.dict_examp: Trains are still running, despite the snow.
senses.lear_examp: There is an easy way to get to the college: a service bus runs every 15 minutes, and the journey takes only 20 minutes.

senses.sense: If liquid runs somewhere, it flows.
senses.dict_examp: Tears ran down her face.
senses.lear_examp: Tears ran down my cold cheek as my numb fingers opened the envelope.

senses.sense: If you run a computer program, you use it on your computer.
senses.dict_examp: Did you run a virus check this morning?
senses.lear_examp: At this point the computer is unable to run any program.

senses.sense: If a piece of equipment is running, it is switched on and working, and if you run it, you switch it on and make it work.
senses.dict_examp: She left the engine running while she went into the store.
senses.lear_examp: The dish washer was delivered in time and installed as well, though we could not actually run the machine at that time.

senses.sense: to publish something in a newspaper or magazine

senses.sense: to try to get elected

senses.lear_examp: In addition, I would like to suggest that aspects of his life when he was running for mayor should be included in the form of a speech by himself.

senses.sense: to move something along/over/through, etc., something else

senses.sense: to be at a particular level
